questions.question: Question 1: The Pap smear of a healthy 30-year-old lady is given below. Identify the microorganism seen.
questions.explanation:
The organism seen in the given image of a Pap smear is the Doderlien’s bacillus, also known as 
Lactobacillus. This is a gram-positive, rod-shaped bacillus that grows in anaerobic conditions. It is a part of the normal vaginal flora that is responsible for the vaginal defence mechanism. It is an estrogen-dependent bacillus and appears at puberty and disappears after menopause. It converts glycogen into lactic acid and maintains the acidic ph in the vagina. This prevents the 
growth of pathogenic bacteria in the vagina. Its absence causes a condition called bacterial 
vaginosis where pathogenic organisms replaces the normal flora of the vagina. In this condition, 
clue cells are visible. Option B: Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common organism involved in bacterial vaginosis. As 
the patient in the given question is healthy, this is not the correct option. Option C: Trichomonas vaginalis is flagellated protozoa that causes trichomonas vaginitis. The 
organism and the nucleus of epithelial cells appear equal in size on the pap smear. This criterion 
is used for the identification of trichomonas as flagella are not visible on a pap smear. Option D: Frisch bacillus is another name for Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It is not seen on Pap 
smears.

questions.question:
Question 2: All of the following are risk factors for PID except 
.
questions.explanation:
Pregnancy is not a risk factor for PID. Instead, it plays a protective role in this condition. 739 
Sold by @itachibot The risk factors for developing PID are: • Unprotected sexual intercourse • Having multiple sex partners • Previous history of PID • IUD insertion • Early age of sexual intercourse (<18years) The protective factors for PID are: • Pregnancy • Using barrier contraception like condoms, diaphragms • Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) • Menopause

questions.question:
Question 3: 731 
Sold by @itachibot A 24-year-old woman is diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease. Which of the following 
is not included in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Cervicitis is not included in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Pelvic inflammatory disease is a spectrum of infection and inflammation of the upper genital 
tract, typically causing: • Endometritis • Salpingitis • Oophoritis • Peritonitis The minimum criteria for diagnosis of PID are: Pain in the lower abdomen + any one of the following: • Uterine tenderness • Cervical motion tenderness • Adnexal tenderness Cervicitis and vaginitis are lower genital tract infections.

questions.question: Question 4: What is the most common symptom seen in acute PID?

options.d: Pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen

questions.explanation:
The most common symptom of acute PID is bilateral lower abdominal pain. The pain is severe in acute stages and it may or may not be accompanied by a high temperature ( 
>38.3 degrees C). It may be followed by vomiting. Some patients with PID can present with pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. This is 
seen in Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome which is a form of perihepatitis. 740 
Sold by @itachibot If PID occurs due to sexually transmitted organisms, dysuria and vaginal discharge may be seen.

questions.question:
Question 5: A young woman with fever and lower abdominal pain is diagnosed to have PID. Which is the 
most common cause for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of PID. PID is an infection of the upper genital tract. It is generally transmitted sexually as an ascending 
infection along with sperms. It is usually a polymicrobial infection, Organisms causing PID include: Sexually transmitted: • Chlamydia (most common) • Gonococcus • Mycoplasma • Trichomonas Pyogenic Aerobes: • Staphylococci • Streptococci • E Coli Anaerobes: • Bacteroides fragilis • Peptostreptococcus • Clostridium • Actinomyces (most common in IUD users) Other: • Mycobacterium tuberculosis Note: Genital tuberculosis is the only PID that does not spread sexually. It has a hematogenous 
spread. Thus, it is the most common PID in virgin girls.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 42-year-old woman presented to the emergency room with abdominal pain and fever for 
the last 48 hours. She has been using a Cu T 380A for contraception for the past 8 years. On 
examination, cervical motion tenderness was present. What is the most likely organism to 
have caused her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of PID in an IUCD user. The most common 
organism causing this condition is Actinomyces. It has been reported in 7% of IUCD users if the 
device is worn for more than 2 years. This emphasizes the need for strict asepsis during insertion of the device and the need for strict 
follow up of women wearing these devices. Organisms causing PID are: 741 
Sold by @itachibot Sexually transmitted: • Chlamydia (most common) • Gonococcus • Mycoplasma • Trichomonas Pyogenic Aerobes: • Staphylococci • Streptococci • E Coli Anaerobes: • Bacteroides fragilis • Peptostreptococcus • Clostridium • Actinomyces (most common in IUD users) Other: • Mycobacterium tuberculosis

questions.question:
Question 7: What is the mechanism of the spread of gonococci to the tubes in pelvic inflammatory 
disease?
questions.explanation:
The mechanism of the spread of gonococci to the tubes in pelvic inflammatory disease is mucosal. Gonococci ascend to the tubes mainly through mucosal continuity. This is facilitated by sexually 
transmitted vectors such as sperms and Trichomonas. The mucous membranes of the fallopian tubes are affected first. They become edematous and are 
infiltrated with leukocytes and plasma cells. Another route of spread is through the reflux of 
mucosal blood. Option A: Hematogenous spread is seen in genital tuberculosis. Option B: Lymphatics are involved in the spread of secondary organisms and in PID following 
post-abortal and puerperal infection. Option C: Parametrium facilitates the spread of Mycoplasma. The gut flora can directly spread to 
tubes.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which infection causes more damage to the mucosa and the wall of the tube leading to 
fibrosis and tubal blockage?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, chlamydial infection causes the most amount of damage to the mucosa 
and the wall of the fallopian tubes leading to fibrosis and tubal blockage. 742 
Sold by @itachibot Chlamydial infection can remain asymptomatic in the endo-cervix. Hence, the infection goes 
unnoticed and untreated. Thus, it can lead to more damage and complications. Gonococcal infection is more symptomatic than chlamydial infection. Hence, it is diagnosed early 
and causes less damage to the tubes than chlamydial infection. Mycoplasma and Mobiluncus generally cause lower genital tract infections like cervicitis and 
vaginitis.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis of acute PID?
questions.explanation:
Pelvic endometriosis is not a differential diagnosis of acute PID. It is a differential diagnosis of 
chronic PID. Differential diagnosis of acute PID: • Acute appendicitis • Septic abortion • Cholecystitis • Twisted ovarian cyst • Ectopic pregnancy • Diverticulitis • Ruptured endometriotic cyst Differential diagnosis of chronic PID: • Uterine fibroids • Pelvic endometriosis • Ovarian tumour • Tubercular tubo-ovarian mass

questions.question:
Question 10: A 26-year-old female with endometritis did not complete the course of antibiotics she was 
prescribed. Following this, her infection failed to resolve and she developed a tubo-ovarian 
mass. How can this mass manifest?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of development of a chronic tubo-ovarian mass following acute PID points 
towards a diagnosis of chronic PID. A chronic tubo-ovarian mass can manifest as a tubo-ovarian 
cyst, hydrosalpinx or even a chronic pyosalpinx. Failure to complete treatment of acute PID or drug resistance can lead to the development of 
chronic PID. This can lead to the development of chronic tubo-ovarian masses which may 
manifest as: • Hydrosalpinx • Chronic pyosalpinx • Chronic interstitial salpingitis 743 
Sold by @itachibot • Tubo-ovarian cyst • Tuberculous form A twisted ovarian cyst and a ruptured endometriotic cyst are differential diagnoses of acute PID.

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition seen in the image 
given below?

options.c: Flattening of tubal plicae is seen on histology
options.d: Its ampullary region is filled with clear fluid

questions.explanation:
The above image depicts a hydrosalpinx. Its wall is not opaque but translucent. If a pyosalpinx responds to antibiotics, the pus present inside becomes sterile within 6 weeks of 
the initial attack. However, the damage to the tube remains as chronic pyosalpinx or 
hydrosalpinx. A hydrosalpinx represents the end result of previous acute salpingitis and is often 
bilateral. The tube becomes retort shaped due to the enormous dilatation of the ampullary region that is 
filled with clear fluid. Histological examination shows a flattening of the tubal plicae and exfoliation of the lining 
epithelium.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient with fever and abdominal pain presented to the emergency. On examination, you 
note mucopurulent vaginal discharge and cervical motion tenderness. You suspect she has 
PID. Which of these is not included in the criteria to diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation:
Bilateral abdominal pain is not included in the criteria to diagnose PID. Bilateral abdominal pain 
is a clinical symptom of PID. Lower abdominal tenderness is included in the criteria to diagnose PID. CDC criteria for the diagnosis of PID: Definitive criteria: • Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy • Imaging study (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (tubo-ovarian abscess) • Laparoscopic evidence of PID Minimum criteria: • Cervical motion tenderness • Uterine tenderness • Adnexal tenderness Additional criteria: • Oral temperature >38.3 oC • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge, cervical friability • Raised ESR or CRP • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia 744 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not a definitive criterion used to diagnose PID?
questions.explanation:
A temperature of more than 38.3°C is an additional criterion and not a definitive criterion for the 
diagnosis of PID. CDC 2006 criteria for the diagnosis of PID: Definitive criteria: • Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy • Imaging studies (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (Tubo-ovarian abscess) • Laparoscopic evidence of PID Minimum criteria: • Lower abdominal tenderness • Adnexal tenderness • Cervical motion tenderness Additional criteria: • Oral temperature>38.3C • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability • Raised ESR or CRP • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia

questions.question:
Question 14: A 24-year-old woman presented with bilateral abdominal pain for 3 days and a temperature 
of 102°F. She also had a mucopurulent vaginal discharge, cervical motion tenderness, and a 
negative urine pregnancy test. Which is the gold standard investigation to confirm her likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is likely to be acute PID. Laparoscopy is the gold standard to confirm 
acute PID. Laparoscopy is not done routinely as it is an invasive procedure. It is reserved for only cases 
where the differential diagnosis is salpingitis, appendicitis, ectopic pregnancy or a case of a 
non-responding pelvic mass. The diagnosis of PID is mostly clinical. If diagnosis is unclear, the investigation of choice for PID 
is USG and culdocentesis. CDC 2006 criteria for the diagnosis of PID: Definitive criteria: • Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy • Imaging studies (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (tubo-ovarian abscess) • Laparoscopic evidence of PID Minimum criteria: 745 
Sold by @itachibot • Lower abdominal tenderness • Adnexal tenderness • Cervical motion tenderness Additional criteria: • Oral temperature>38.3C • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability • Raised ESR or CRP • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia

questions.question:
Question 16: In a patient with PID, laparoscopy shows the following appearance. What is true about the 
syndrome this patient likely has? 735 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows the laparoscopic finding of violin string adhesions that are characteristic 
of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. It is a form of perihepatitis that occurs in the setting of PID. It is characterized by right upper quadrant pain with a pleuritic component, sometimes referred to 
the right shoulder. It rarely occurs in women with acute PID. The pathological mechanism is as 
follows: Gonococcal / Chlamydial infection  transperitoneal/vascular spread  inflammation of the liver 
capsule and peritoneal surfaces  adhesions and fibrosis in the perihepatic region 
Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome 746 
Sold by @itachibot Cholecystitis and ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess are the differential diagnoses of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis 
syndrome. Violin string adhesions would not be seen in these conditions.

questions.question: Question 17: Identify the wrong statement with respect to silent PID.

options.d: Mycobacterium can be grown from menstrual blood

questions.explanation:
Dysmenorrhea rarely occurs in PID. Pain is uncommon and is a result of subacute PID. Silent PID is thought to follow multiple or continuous low-grade infections in asymptomatic 
women. It is not a clinical diagnosis. Rather, it is an ultimate diagnosis given to women with 
tubal-factor infertility who lack a history of upper genital tract infection. On laparoscopy or laparotomy, these women may have evidence of prior tubal infection such as 
adhesions, but for the most part, the fallopian tubes are grossly normal. They can have ectopic 
pregnancies due to tubal dysmotility. Silent PID can occur following infection with M. 
tuberculosis.

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient is admitted to the gynaecology ward for pelvic inflammatory disease. Which of the 
following is a part of this patient's treatment regimen?

options.a: Administration of cefotetan 2 g IV 12 hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV BD
options.b: Removal of IUD irrespective of antibiotic response
options.c: Administration of a single dose of ceftriaxone 250 mg IM
options.d: Administration of 10 doses of Placentrex 2ml IM daily or on alternate days

questions.explanation:
Administration of cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV for 48 hours 
forms the crux of the treatment regimen for PID. This is followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg 
+/-metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days in all hospitalized patients having PID. Treatment of PID in hospitalized patients: • Cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV for 48 hours is given followed by 
oral doxycycline 100 mg +/- metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days • Cefoxitin 2 g IV 6hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV followed by oral route. • Azithromycin 500 mg IV 6 hourly for 2 days, then orally for Chlamydia. Outpatient treatment of PID (according to the current RCOG guidelines): • A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- 
metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days • A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by azithromycin 1 gm per week x 2 weeks. IUD is not removed in a woman who responds to antibiotics. It is removed only in case of a failed 
antibiotic response. Barrier contraceptives and OCPs are recommended only in women 
unresponsive to antibiotics. The use of Placentrex (aqueous extract of the placenta) is outdated and is not recommended 
currently.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 30-year-old female presents to the OPD with fever, lower abdominal pain and purulent 
vaginal discharge. On examination, her vitals are stable and per vaginal examination reveals 
lower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness. What is the best treatment option for her?

options.a: Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg with oral doxycycline and metronidazole for 14 days
options.b: Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 7 days
options.c: Oral doxycycline 100 mg BD with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 7 days
options.d: Oral ofloxacin 200 mg BD with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of fever and lower abdominal pain associated with lower abdominal 
and cervical motion tenderness is suggestive of PID. The best treatment option for this patient is 747 
Sold by @itachibot outpatient treatment with a single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD 
+/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days. Outpatient treatment of PID (according to the current RCOG guidelines): • A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mg 
BD x 14 days • A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by azithromycin 1 gm per week x 2 weeks. Treatment of PID in hospitalized patients: • Cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV for 48 hours is given followed by 
oral doxycycline 100 mg +/- metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days • Cefoxitin 2 g IV 6hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV followed by oral route. • Azithromycin 500 mg IV 6 hourly for 2 days, then orally for Chlamydia.

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following would be an indication for surgery in a 30-year-old woman diagnosed 
with PID?
questions.explanation:
Intestinal obstruction would be an indication for surgery in a patient diagnosed with PID. Criteria for surgery in PID include: • Drainage of pelvic abscess by colpotomy. • Dilatation and evacuation of septic products of conception or for haemorrhage in the postabortal 
period. • Acute spreading peritonitis resistant to a full course of chemotherapy. Presence of 
pyoperitoneum mandates laparotomy. • Intestinal obstruction • Suspected intestinal injury as diagnosed in criminal abortion. • Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess A tubo-ovarian abscess of 2 cm is not an indication for surgery. Minimally invasive surgery is 
done in a tubo-ovarian abscess measuring more than 10 cm, that fails to respond to antibiotics in 
48-72 hours. Peritonitis and sepsis are not an indication for surgery. They should be managed medically first. If 
they do not respond to antibiotic treatment then surgical management should be done.

questions.question:
Question 21: Which among the following is an indication for minimally invasive surgery for tubo-ovarian 
abscess?

options.a: The size of the abscess is more than 5 cm
options.b: The size of the abscess is more than 2cm
options.c: The abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 48 - 72 h
options.d: The abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 24 - 36 h

questions.explanation:
If the abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 48–72 h, minimally invasive surgery is indicated. Criteria for minimally invasive surgery in PID: • The size of the abscess is more than 10 cm • The abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 48-72 hours 748 
Sold by @itachibot • The abscess ruptures • Pyoperitoneum Minimal invasive surgery includes laparoscopic drainage of the tubo ovarian abscess or posterior 
colpotomy.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 55-year-old multiparous woman who presented with chronic lower abdominal pain has 
been diagnosed with chronic PID. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The treatment of choice for an old multiparous woman with chronic PID is abdominal 
hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. A radical hysterectomy involves the removal of the whole uterus, tissue from the sides of the 
uterus, the cervix, and the upper part of the vagina. It is generally done only in cancer patients. A supracervical hysterectomy involves the removal of only the body of the uterus and is not done 
in chronic PID. It is done for the treatment of endometriosis, uterine fibroids, and uterine 
prolapse.

questions.question: Question 23: Who has described the prognostic evaluation for PID?
questions.explanation:
Boer-Meisel has described the prognostic evaluation for PID. It depends upon the following: • Extent of adhesions • Nature of adhesions such as flimsy or dense. • Size of hydrosalpinx • Macroscopic condition of hydrosalpinx. • The thickness of the tubal wall. Boer-Meisel system is specifically used for predicting pregnancy outcomes in patients treated for 
PID. Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage. Westrom has reported that women with one previous attack of PID have a predisposition to 
another attack. Stages of PID Stage I

questions.question: Question 24: Long-standing pelvic inflammation may lead to which of the following conditions?

options.d: It commonly presents as a unilateral condition

questions.explanation:
Long-standing pelvic inflammation may lead to pyometra. This refers to the collection of pus in 
the uterine cavity. The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, 
skene glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes. Unilateral pain and swelling over the labia may 
be caused by the inflammation of the Bartholin glands. Depending on the extent of tissue involved, PID can be classified into five stages • Stage I - Acute salpingitis without peritonitis - No adhesions • Stage II - Acute salpingitis with peritonitis - purulent discharge • Stage III - Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo ovarian complex • Stage IV - Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess • Stage V - Tubercular salpingitis Long-standing pelvic inflammation may also lead to: • Dyspareunia • Infertility • Ectopic pregnancy • Formation of adhesions like hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx, tubo-ovarian abscess • Chronic pelvic pain Note: Chronic pelvic inflammation leads to dense adhesions between the uterus and the 
appendages. Thus, it becomes difficult to define the uterus from the pelvic masses. They form a 
hard mass which is called the frozen pelvis. The most common cause of the spread of PID: Ascending infection along with sperms The only PID that does not spread with the sexual route is genital TB. It has a hematogenous 
spread. The most common PID in virgin females is genital TB. Investigation of choice in PID: Abdominal USG The surest sign of salpingitis is pus extruding from the fimbrial end of the tube. 750 
Sold by @itachibot Genital Tuberculosis
